title: Arizona doesn't do nearly enough to prevent child abuse
description: A sole focus on investigating child abuse reports won't keep children safe. Arizona needs a stronger system to support families before crisis occurs.
content:
The deaths of Arizona children Rebekah Baptiste, Emily Pike and Zariah Dodd are unacceptable tragedies. No child should experience abuse, and no family should suffer such loss.

When abuse is suspected, it must be reported.

But focusing only on reporting and investigation does not keep children safe. Nor does over-reporting prevent harm to children. It overwhelms the system, drives unnecessary investigations and erodes trust, making families less likely to seek the help that could prevent crises.

Arizona needs a stronger, better-connected system that links families to support before crisis occurs. We know what works: strategies like affordable childcare, accessible health care and Family Resource Centers, which are hubs of support for people raising children.

These proven solutions not only protect kids, they yield massive economic and social returns.

Our attention shouldn’t all be on improving DCS. Policymakers — and all of us — share the responsibility to create conditions that allow families to thrive.

Prevention is possible, and it’s the best way to keep children safe. It not only avoids unimaginable tragedy, but also creates an Arizona that is a great place to be child.

Are the DBacks even a Major League team?

The Arizona Diamondbacks, as they have become prone to do, blew another lead to the last-place Colorado Rockies. Without relief pitching, it is a stretch to call them a Major League team.

Regarding The Arizona Republic story, “In Arizona's 'New Age Capital,' Sedona spiritualists are turning to Trump and the right:”

Is it that difficult to believe?

The MAGA movement wants smaller government and less interference. It wants to talk with our adversaries and avoid war. It sees big-government establishment people as profiteers making money off “public service.”

When MAGA took over the House, Senate and White House, today’s rebels were replacing the establishment. Party affiliation is not all that relevant.

So, the “Golden Age” is not too far removed from the “New Age.”

Bark beetles are kind of like Trump

In 1998, our family owned a cabin northwest of Payson. One afternoon as we pulled into the driveway, my wife pointed out that the needles at the top of a 60-foot ponderosa pine had turned brown. Three smaller trees were in the same condition.

In 2016, during his first campaign for president, Donald Trump said that news stories that cast him in a bad light were just fake news. We should only believe what he tells us to believe, he said.

I thought, this guy doesn’t have a chance. The second time around, Mr. Trump said we wouldn’t need to worry about the next election if he won this one. What did that mean?

MAGA gobbled up the U.S. Senate and House. The U.S. Supreme Court issued a get out of jail free card. And, on the president’s orders, masked men started dragging people off city streets.

What would be next, I wondered, troops?

Back in 1998, when the tree specialist schooled me on the bark beetle, I asked, what can I do to save the other trees?

He looked at me sideways and shook his head.

You don’t know it yet, but those trees are already dead.

Nasty WNBA game stunt is all about attitude

This was unusual for me, but E.J. Montini's column “You can bet how many sex toys will land on WNBA courts. That’s the problem” brought me over to his side with his insights about the young man who made a stunt out of throwing a sex toy on the court.

His motive? He thought “he would give it a try.”

Fortunately, he was arrested, even though his aim was terrible and he didn’t hit the court. Rather, he missed and hit a fan in the head. Talk about missing the broadside of a barn. Apparently, he has some manhood issues.

But Mr. Montini, I think, missed some points.

This man, whose name is hidden for some reason, will say or perhaps has said he is sorry. He will look contrite, his eyes looking down. “I’m sorry, your honor. I didn’t think this through, and I didn’t mean to hurt anyone ... blah, blah, blah.”

More letters: If Arizona still needs a gas pipeline in 2029, we're all cooked

I’m guessing he won’t mean it. And were you to follow him around since his incident and watch him look at his friends, there would be hidden smiles.

That is the issue. His attitude is probably ingrained, and he won’t change.

The story of Peoria restaurant owner Kelly Yu (“Kelly Yu, Peoria restaurant owner, facing deportation under Trump administration”) says a lot about what is wrong with the Trump administration’s immigration policies. It also says a lot about what is wrong with us.

Kelly Yu did come to this country illegally. But since, she has given birth to a U.S. citizen daughter, got married, started a successful business that employs many people, followed all the rules towards achieving citizenship and gave back to her community.

And her reward for all that effort?

Sitting in a detention center in Eloy awaiting deportation. That makes no sense.

I don’t think people who have U.S. citizen children should be eligible for deportation unless they commit a serious crime. I also don’t think we should deport people whose contributions to our country outweigh any illegal entry decades ago.

There needs to be some calculation of the cost of removal. In other words, what are we losing by removing someone from our country and their community?

With Kelly Yu, it seems like we are losing a lot. A mother, a wife, a taxpayer who employs dozens of other taxpayers, a popular restaurant owner, a community participant.

She seems like someone we should recruit to be here.

What’s on your mind? Send us a letter to the editor online or via email at opinions@arizonarepublic.com.

This article originally appeared on Arizona Republic: Arizona DCS is important. But it alone can't keep kids safe | Letters

You can bet how many sex toys will land on WNBA courts. That's the problem | Opinion
It's happening because we are living at a time and in a country where our toxic 'bro' culture makes the morons among us feel comfortable doing so.
- Individuals have thrown sex toys onto the court during WNBA games, prompting discussion about motivations and cultural implications.
- The act is an attempt to humiliate female athletes and is linked to broader issues of sexism and misogyny in sports.
- Online betting sites have offered wagers related to the incidents, further highlighting the normalization of such behavior.
The idiots who’ve tossed sex toys onto the basketball court during WNBA games will never be able to adequately explain why they did it.
Or tried to do it.
On a few occasions the toy tossers actually came up short. (Feel free to insert perpetrator insult here.)
The 18-year-old arrested for having tried to throw a sex toy onto the court during a game between the Phoenix Mercury and the Connecticut Sun — and who ended up hitting a spectator — said he saw the stunt talked about on social media and decided to give it a try.
In other words, he did it because he could. He did it because he lives at a time and in country where our toxic “bro” culture made him feel comfortable doing so.
Throwing sex toys is an attempt to humiliate
As Shannon Ryan wrote in The Athletic, “Humiliation, often lewd or sexual, has long been used as an attempt to make women feel uncomfortable in sports or diminish their place in this space.
“In these recent incidents, it’s a stretch to argue targeting the WNBA wasn’t strategic and intentional. Making a sex toy the focal point of games in a league that has perhaps the most openly gay and queer players doesn’t seem like an accident either.”
No, it does not.
Reports also indicate that a group of crypto creeps used the initial incident to try to boost the value of a memecoin, the kind of monetary exchange when an internet meme becomes traded in real online markets.
It’s an area of the financial industry that has gotten a big boost from President Donald Trump.
WNBA calls it 'unacceptable.' That's the wrong word
WNBA commissioner Cathy Engelbert calls what’s happening “unacceptable.” Although, “unacceptable” might be the wrong word.
One of the ways we learn these days about what is accepted, or not accepted, is if it can be wagered on.
Online betting operations have been taking wagers on what has happened at WNBA games. The site Polymarket said that $460,000 was bet on whether another sex toy would be thrown at a WNBA game by Aug. 8.
Another site featured a series of proposition bets that included an over/under on how many sex toys would hit the court over the course of the season (7.5) and other equally gross hypotheses.
That says a lot about how comfortable we are with sexism and misogyny.
Luckily, those creeps aren't dealing with Taurasi
Minnesota Lynx head coach Cheryl Reeve said, “This has been going on for centuries … The sexualization of women is what’s used to hold women down, and this is no different. This is its latest form, and we should write about it in that way.”
Yeah, we should.
But in the end I’d also prefer the counteraction proposed by the now-retired Phoenix Mercury great Diana Taurasi.
Asked how she would have responded to a sex toy landing on the court while she was playing, Taurasi said, “I would have picked that thing up and thrown it right back at them.”
Reach Montini at ed.montini@arizonarepublic.com.

At least an Arizona senator is asking why kids have died on DCS' watch | Opinion
Before Emily, Zariah and Rebekah, there were Anndreah, Liana and Za'Naya. Please, God, let's not go there again.
- Arizona's Department of Child Safety (DCS), created to replace the inadequate Child Protective Services (CPS), is failing to protect vulnerable children.
- The recent deaths of three girls, Emily Pike, Zariah Finley Dodd and Rebekah Baptiste, should be our wake-up call.
- Sen. Carine Werner has launched a task force to investigate and propose solutions.
It’s been 11 years now since the state dismantled the woeful Arizona Child Protective Services and in its place created the Arizona Department of Child Safety.
After decades of horror stories and graveyards full of dead kids, it was, I hoped, a new day for vulnerable children in Arizona.
Yes, I still see you, Anndreah and Isaac and 2-year-old China Marie, who endured 15 broken bones over time before finally dying in 1993, just two weeks after a state child-welfare official declared that she was “thriving.”
The day when the right of a child to grow up would supersede the right of a lousy parent to get a second or third or fourth chance to screw up.
DCS failed kids then and is again now
I still see you, too, TaJuana and Emily and 20-month-old Liana, your broken body wired to a rock and tossed into a canal in 2001 after CPS found no evidence of abuse.
The day when a black eye would be cause for prompt and decisive action … or at least some hard questions asked.
And you, Odessa, 5, and your 3-year-old brother Henry, beaten to death and stuffed down a sewer hole in 1994 after at least six reports to CPS.
The day when the agency, tasked with a tough job, would confront its own shortcomings and err on the side of the children they are there to protect.
Sadly, that day has not yet come. Or it came and now, tragically, has gone again.
Now, there is a new generation of children beyond our help, failed either by DCS or by other agencies and contractors charged with protecting children.
Kids like Emily Pike, 14
The San Carlos Apache Tribal Social Services Department placed Emily in a DCS-licensed group home in Mesa in 2023 after she was sexually assaulted by a relative.
Emily, who had lived all her life in the tiny eastern Arizona town of Peridot, was reportedly home sick and unhappy. But the right hand didn’t talk to the left hand when it might have mattered, and in January she left.
Because Emily was in the custody of the tribe, certain reporting requirements aimed at quickly finding out where she might have gone didn’t apply to her.
Perhaps it wouldn’t have mattered. Children who go missing from group homes often are considered runaways. They’ll turn up, or so the thinking seems to go.
Emily did eventually turn up 18 days later. Her dismembered remains were found in two black garbage bags dumped along a highway near Globe.
Kids like Zariah Finley Dodd, 16
Zariah was 5 when DCS came into her life. She’d been pushing her infant brother down the street in his stroller, knocking on doors and asking for food.
Apparently, she’d been taking care of her half-brother for most of a week after their mother disappeared.
Zariah was placed with a foster family, and for 11 months, she got to be a little girl.
“I get a bed?” she asked her foster mother that first day, when shown her new home.
But the foster mother told The Arizona Republic’s Jose R. Gonzalez that DCS prioritized Zariah’s birth family and moved her out of the home 11 months later.
She would spend the next decade bouncing around close to 20 foster homes until finally leaving her final group home on July 4.
Her body was found the next morning in a west Phoenix park. She’d been shot in the head.
The 36-year-old man who had gotten her pregnant and another man await trial in her murder.
Kids like Rebekah Baptiste, 10
DCS was in and out of Rebekah’s life for years and relatives say her parents lost custody due to drug abuse. But she and her two brothers were returned to their father.
Over the last year or so, the kids’ school called DCS 12 times with concerns about the Baptiste children.
The school’s resource officer visited the family’s Phoenix home in April, to see why Rebekah been absent for several days.
He found the child with a black eye.
Phoenix police contacted DCS that day and four other times beginning in 2018.
Rebekah died on July 30. She’d been beaten, burned, starved.
Tortured, as one doctor put it.
Her short life must have been a living hell, as records show doctors found extensive evidence of long-term abuse, including missing toenails and burn marks.
Her father and his girlfriend have been arrested.
DCS is playing duck and cover again
DCS is, of course, heartbroken, even as it plays duck and cover.
“Tragically, those who intend to harm children can sometimes evade even the most robust systems designed to protect them,” the agency’s statement said, before vowing to investigate itself a la CPS (which always managed to clear itself of any wrongdoing).
To investigate a system so “robust” that it managed to ignore a dozen or more calls for help.
DCS, again echoing a claim I heard over and over again in the bad old days of CPS, claims the school called only five times over the last year and of those, only one met the legal criteria for an investigation.
Please. If a school is repeatedly raising a red flag — and the police as well — and that’s not enough to prompt a look-see, then exactly how many calls does it take before a child can get help?
That would be a good question for Sen. Carine Werner to ask.
While DCS pays CYA, the Scottsdale Republican has convened a task force to discover what went wrong and how to fix it.
“The deaths of Emily Pike, Zariah Dodd and Rebekah Baptiste should be a wake-up call for us all,” she said earlier this month. “These tragedies make it painfully clear that when our child protection systems — both state and tribal — fail, the consequences can be horrific. We cannot allow these failures to repeat.”
An Arizona senator is stepping in. Good for her
She is right. We simply can’t look away.
Not again.
Nothing changed over the years at CPS until finally a few dogged lawmakers, with a little help from county prosecutors and others, dug in to the agency and dug out the gruesome details that put far, far too many children into early graves.
Laws were changed, the agency was remade, the mission was clarified and the pressure was on as the eyes of the state focused steadfastly on the children who were going, going, gone.
Yes, I still see you, Jacob and Jhessye and 22-month-old Za’Naya, who starved to death in 2012 while CPS was supposed to be watching.
And Tyler and Ariana and 5-year-old Brandon, who upon his 2007 death on CPS’s watch had scars on his arms and ankles from being tied up and blisters on his feet from having been immersed in scalding water.
Now there is Emily and Zariah and Rebekah.
And there is Sen. Werner, hoping to stop the latest sad roll call at three.
Good for you, Sen. Werner. Good for you.
Reach Roberts at laurie.roberts@arizonarepublic.com. Follow her on X (formerly Twitter) at @LaurieRobertsaz, on Threads at @LaurieRobertsaz and on BlueSky at @laurieroberts.bsky.social.

Arizona Diamondbacks blow 5-run lead in loss to Colorado Rockies
DENVER — The Arizona Diamondbacks coughed up a five-run lead and lost 10-7 to the Colorado Rockies on Saturday, Aug. 16, at Coors Field.
Down 7-4, the Rockies scored six runs in the bottom of the eighth inning, most of those against reliever Andrew Hoffman. Hoffman (1-1) was charged with four earned runs allowed on two hits and two walks in one-third of an inning.
"Didn't execute, pretty simple," Hoffman said after the game. "Walk two guys, you put yourself in a (tough) situation.
Rockies pinch hitter Kyle Farmer drove in the tying run off Diamondbacks reliever Andrew Saalfrank, then the go-ahead run scored on the play when left fielder Lourdes Gurriel Jr. bobbled the ball in the outfield.
Tyler Freeman then hit a two-run home run off Saalfrank to effectively seal a loss for the Diamondbacks (60-64). Freeman turned and flipped his bat without even watching the ball fly over the left field wall.
Diamondbacks manager Torey Lovullo noted that the bullpen hadn't had a blowup like Saturday's in some time. Over the previous eight games, the relief crew had posted a 1.88 earned run average.
"This is tough to absorb," he said. "It is Coors Field. There's no safe lead. At the end of the day, we've got to pitch and catch, throw strikes and make plays. And we didn't at the most critical time of the game."
Adrian Del Castillo hit a two-run home run, Ketel Marte had two doubles and Gurriel Jr. drove in three runs for the Diamondbacks. Del Castillo drove in three runs on the night with a double and his second home run of the season in the top of the seventh inning.
Starting pitcher Ryne Nelson turned in 6⅓ innings of work, allowing four runs on eight hits. He struck out four.
"They've got some guys who can swing it and put some tough at-bats together," Nelson said of the Rockies. "Playing here as well is a little bit of a different element. So credit to them."
Diamondbacks fans talk about fandom, state of team
Arizona Diamondbacks fans show up at every major league ballpark across the country to support their team.
The Arizona Republic met several this week while on the road covering the Diamondbacks' four-game series against the Colorado Rockies. Here's what they had to say about being fans of the team and the current state of the franchise.
First up was Nogales resident Zarette Heredia, 31, who wore the new purple-and-teal Serpientes City Connect jersey while visiting the National Ballpark Museum, just a few steps away from Coors Field in Denver.
Heredia said she was sad to see Eugenio Suarez get traded to the Seattle Mariners, and that the team needs to fix its pitching. Her favorite Diamondback is Marte. Heredia hopes for fewer injuries next season and looks forward to getting LHP Corbin Burnes back from surgery rehab.
"Everyone has been having bad opinions but I stay optimistic about my DBacks," Heredia said. "I'm pretty glad they're doing well, staying in that (wild card) race."
Heredia's favorite memory as a fan was watching the 2001 World Series as a kid with her grandmother on the Mexico side of Nogales. It's what made her a fan, and she has a Luis Gonzalez jersey.
Heredia makes the 2½-hour drive north to Phoenix from Nogales many times to watch the Diamondbacks at Chase Field. She's a partial plan season ticket holder for the first time this year, and has already been to 15 games.
She also enjoys watching the Diamondbacks on the road, traveling to Tampa, Miami and Boston to see them play last season and New York this season, and plans her Diamondbacks ventures around work.
Here are two more Diamondbacks fans, including Matthew Griffith of Paradise Valley, who calls himself a "10 out of 10" fan of the team.
There were plenty of Diamondbacks fans in the seats at Coors Field on Friday, Aug. 15, many sitting behind the visiting team's dugout along the first base side.
DBacks to add pitcher for start Aug. 17
Lovullo named the starting pitcher for Sunday, Aug. 17, and it will be RHP Nabil Crismatt, who has joined the team in Denver. A corresponding roster move to add him to the active roster had yet to be made Saturday night.
Crismatt is a veteran who has pitched for four major league teams, including a one-game stint with the Diamondbacks in 2023. He was signed to a minor league deal last week and made one appearance with Triple-A Reno.
Crismatt made 19 starts at Triple-A Lehigh Valley this year before being released by the Phillies organization on Aug. 4.
"He's able to come into this environment and pitch and put balls over the plate, and that's what we're looking for," Lovullo said. "He's pretty stretched out. He's going to go as far as he can."
No timetable for return of players on injured list
Lovullo said there is no target date for the return of rehabbing players Gabriel Moreno, Pavin Smith, Ildemaro Vargas and pitcher Ryan Thompson, but Moreno, Smith and Vargas continue to play games at Triple-A Reno.
"Sooner rather than later, yeah," Lovullo said of Moreno, who is catching and hitting in games. "He could wind up in the series on Monday (home vs. Cleveland) and he could wind up playing with us after the off day."
The Diamondbacks' next day off is Aug. 21. Lovullo added that he might not play Marte on Sunday, as the manager feels it's risky to play him four straight days in Colorado.
A forceful Marte swing late in the game was cause for a little concern, but Marte said he felt OK.
Diamondbacks at Rockies, Aug. 16, 5:10 p.m., Cox, Ch. 34
Diamondbacks RHP Ryne Nelson (6-3, 3.46) vs. Rockies RHP Chase Dollander (2-9, 6.35).
At Coors Field: Nelson has had a loss and three no-decisions since his most recent win on July 19. In his last start, Nelson allowed five earned runs on seven hits in 5⅓ innings at Texas. ... He hasn't faced the Rockies this season, but has not fared well against them in the past. In two starts, he's allowed 11 earned runs on 17 hits, though Nelson has a win against them. He has allowed two or fewer earned runs in four of his last five starts.. ... Dollander, 23, made his major league debut in April. He's spent parts of this season at Triple-A Albuquerque and has had a stint on the 15-day injured list with forearm tightness. Dollander gave up one run in 4⅔ innings at Chase Field back in May, a game the Diamondbacks won 1-0.
Coming up
Sunday, Aug. 17: At Colorado, 12:10 p.m., Diamondbacks RHP Nabil Crismatt (0-0, 0.00) vs. Rockies RHP Antonio Senzatela (4-14, 7.34)
Monday, Aug. 18: At Chase Field, 6:40 p.m. Diamondbacks RHP Zac Gallen (9-12, 5.31) vs. Guardians RHP Gavin Williams (7-4, 3.38).
Tuesday, Aug. 19: At Chase Field, 6:40 p.m., Diamondbacks LHP Eduardo Rodriguez (5-7, 5.40) vs. Guardians RHP Tanner Bibee (9-9, 4.54).

In Arizona's 'New Age Capital,' Sedona spiritualists are turning to Trump and the right
- Sedona, known for its New Age spirituality, sees a shift toward right-wing ideologies among its residents.
- Mistrust of institutions and experts, along with a desire for personal sovereignty, fuels this political shift.
- The COVID-19 pandemic and vaccine skepticism further solidified this alignment with the right.
SEDONA ― Three years ago, Shelley Evans submitted garbled documents to the Coconino County Recorder’s Office, demanding $12 million for violations of her constitutionally guaranteed rights, in a tactic experts on right-wing radicalization have called "paper terrorism."
Two years ago, officials sued her under a statute that punishes wrongful liens, leaving her on the hook for roughly $55,000, a sum she would later report was roughly equal to her net assets.
She tried, in the wake of the verdict, to navigate the Chapter 11 bankruptcy process without a lawyer. She failed.
Nine months later, still seized with indignation and figuring out her financial future, Evans invited her discussion group to come together in meditation.
The circle of 10 or so people joined hands.
They gave thanks for each other and their weekly “conscious conversation” about the state of the world, this time focused on the promise and perils of artificial intelligence.
They breathed together, chests rising and falling, as the room darkened with the setting sun.
For a moment they were still.
At the end of a winding gravel road in Sedona, Evans has repurposed a yoga studio into the headquarters of Ultimate Light Mission, a spiritual hub “where all paths converge in a unified vision.”
The Sedona chapter of Children’s Health Defense, the anti-vaccine group long chaired by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., meets there every few weeks.
A monthly informational session encourages people to put their money into decentralized cryptocurrency ledgers off the mainstream financial grid, out of reach of the government and regulators.
They meditate. They make meals in bulk for local shelters. They train in martial arts.
Known for its energy-rich vortex sites, Sedona has become an international destination for New Age spirituality, the mystical, peace-loving, pro-environment scene that attracts those who seek a “higher” state of consciousness.
The instinct left many adherents wary of politics altogether, or sympathetic to the moral valences of the American left. For a time, its most prominent political voice was Marianne Williamson, the spiritualist whose left-wing bids for president in 2020 and 2024 called for a “radically humanitarian agenda” and took aim at the “military industrial complex.”
Now, amid tectonic shifts in national politics and the remaking of U.S. conservatism, Sedona’s hippie ranks are finding a new home on the American right.
Many spiritualists’ long-held hostility toward policy and science experts, penchant for conspiracy, and appetite for personal “sovereignty” leave them with more in common with President Donald Trump than with the bohemian social movements that have captured their attention in the past.
In many cases, Trump is the first political figure in decades they have actively followed and believed in.
Though their lifestyles put them on a cultural fringe, the Sedona mystics are among multitudes of Americans nationwide whose mistrust of institutions are pushing them toward the right. Support for vaccines is reaching historic lows, because of attrition from those who identify with or lean toward the GOP.
The Democratic Party, meanwhile, has molded its identity around a staunch defense of political and scientific institutions. A decade after Trump's political ascent, the party has failed to answer the feeling, widespread among Americans, that something is wrong.
Sedona spiritualists are crafting their own explanations.
For her part, Evans follows in the tradition of “sovereign citizens,” the anti-government movement that the FBI considers “a growing threat to domestic law enforcement.”
Evans declined to talk to The Arizona Republic, "pursuant legal advice."
Anita Dalton, a psychic and entrepreneur who owns Sedona’s Center for the New Age, saw Trump in the spiritually minded salespeople she’s followed over the years, whose habitual run-ins with larceny and fraud laws didn’t deter them from aggressive marketing schemes.
Aila Arya Anam, formerly Paula Green, spent her 30s in the feminist Goddess movement, an “earth-based, witchy” culture oriented around veneration of the divine feminine. It was during the pandemic that she realized her long-held skepticism toward vaccines left her with unlikely political allies.
"That's when all of a sudden I'm like, 'holy crap,'" she said. "I'm aligning with the gun-carrying, cowboy conservative, prepper Arizona population, which I always thought were rednecked and religiously fervent, you know?
"I think a lot of alignments, and categorization, are just like: Where do I belong? Who am I? What the hell is happening?"
Susannah Crockford, an anthropologist at the University of Exeter, immersed herself in Sedona’s spiritual scene for several years while writing her seminal 2021 book, "Ripples of the Universe." She’s observed an overall shift toward “what you might call ‘right-wing-engaged.’”
“It’s only surprising if you didn’t know what their politics were like before,” Crockford said.
Crystals discounted for '10% tariff sale'
If the claims of the New Age movement — that the world is fallen and in need of a spiritual awakening, recovering wisdom that is at once ancient and new — seem far-fetched, a person might come closest to believing them in Sedona, the idyllic city nestled at the foot of red rocks and kept picturesque by a skyrocketing housing market that has priced out all but the very wealthy.
The spiritual sector isn’t spared from those economic pressures, Crockford said. Even psychics have to pay rent. In fact, that was a starting point for her research.
In Sedona, “spirituality offers a way for people to distance themselves from and critique current political and economic norms in America,” Crockford wrote. “Yet they still find themselves monetizing their spiritual practice as a way to both ‘raise their vibration’ and meet their basic needs.”
The way its adherents tell the story, Sedona’s business community initially viewed the New Age scene with skepticism, but gradually warmed to it as it generated a steady flow of tourism and business.
Dalton gives herself credit for being one of the pioneers.
Dalton, whose Center for the New Age's purple mural and signage is one of the first things visitors see driving up State Route 179, grew up in New Jersey. She’s the daughter of an Italian mother who worked in aerospace and an Irish father who worked in a funeral home.
A single mom early in adulthood, Dalton worked as a hairdresser, took some college classes but didn’t finish her degree, and eventually wound up in California, where she worked in real estate and prided herself as one of the first women to work in car sales. She nursed a spiritual practice while building an upper-middle-class lifestyle on the California coast, keeping a big house in San Diego with a Cadillac in the garage.
Along the way, she was inspired by figures who blended spirituality with sales.
She was drawn to Terry Cole-Whittaker, the reverend who taught her followers to pursue happiness and prosperity as part of a spiritual path.
She lights up talking about the “Global Information Network,” the brainchild of Kevin Trudeau, the embattled salesman whose eventual 10-year prison sentence a federal appeals court declined to cut short because of the “flagrant and repetitive nature of his contumacious conduct."
Dalton, now in her 70s, has built a durable business selling crystals and other spiritual items, and renting small offices upstairs for $1,100 to $1,600 per month.
Like everyone in the market, Dalton regards herself as a sincere player in a market otherwise corrupted by hucksters and profit-seekers. She embraces the term “New Age,” which others in Sedona’s spiritual community spurn as a cheap and demeaning label, according to Crockford. She paid good money, $30,000 in fact, for a bonafide “aura camera,” which captures the qualities of the person photographed. (Her own aura photo comes back blue, a sign of her psychic abilities.)
Dalton refers to her own religious outlook with self-deprecation (“this God thing”) and speaks about her life as a set of coincidences that guided her, without her conscious knowledge, to the right place.
The core of New Age spirituality, she said, is, “if it feels like truth, embrace it.”
She describes Trump in a similar way. Dalton said she was drawn to him from the moment he came down his golden escalator, for reasons she could not and still cannot quite articulate.
It was “just a feeling,” she said. “You just know when someone’s speaking the truth, or at least, your truth.”
In Dalton’s colorful and bejeweled office, the president’s mugshot is framed next to gray molds of a meditating Buddha figure. On her bookshelf, white lettering stands out from a black spine: MELANIA.
Her Facebook page is a mix of sarcastic swatdowns of Democrats (“I was fired from my job at USAID today. I worked in the woodchuck department. We were so close to finding out how much wood would a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood. Now we will probably never know”) to A.I.-generated praise of Trump and his allies (“Elon Musk turned an abandoned building into a safe haven for 200 orphans. This young dreamer now has a bed, books, and a future…Thanks to Elon’s kindness”).
In April, as Trump’s new tariffs roiled markets and raised fears of an economic downturn, Dalton unfurled a sign in front of her store, in the signature purple color of Sedona psychics’ offices: “10% TARIFF SALE.”
The tariffs modestly impacted her business. Several suppliers called saying they couldn’t fulfill orders for things like books, tarot cards, and candles. One of her suppliers, a stained-glass company, went out of business.
These were “tchotchkes,” Dalton said, waving a hand.
“It was stuff you could live without,” she said. “I psychically know tariffs are a good thing.”
The centerpiece of Dalton’s politics is opposing the “corruption” she says is unfolding in plain sight, which she struggled, when asked, to describe in more detail, but believes can explain recent controversies, such as the media’s handling of former President Joe Biden’s cognitive decline, and even the repeated legal action against Trudeau, the Global Information Network salesman whom she still holds in high regard.
Some liberal political figures are exempt from her scorn. Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vermont, for example, is “too left” for her taste. “But I don’t think he’s corrupt.”
Some believed 'disease of uncertain origins' validated conspiracy theories, expert says
Arriving in Sedona in 2012, Crockford, the anthropologist, quickly learned not to bring up politics.
“They would just be like, ‘Oh, they’re all the same. They’re all corrupt,’” she said.
Broaching the topic was seen as spiritually counterproductive.
“If you say something like, ‘I don’t think like the Democrats,’ or ‘I don’t think this Republican policy is very good,’ what you’re doing is lowering your vibration. You’re doing something spiritually damaging: Not just to you, but to everyone around you.”
That began to change during the COVID-19 pandemic, when political decisions were felt acutely in everyday life.
“It sort of proved all their conspiracy theories correct,” Crockford said. “Here was this disease of uncertain origins.”
“What the government, who they’d always been opposed to for various reasons, was telling them was, ‘stay inside and then get vaccinated,’” she continued. “That explicitly went against how they believe health and immunity work.”
Alex Young is a professor at Arizona State University who studies settler colonialism. He connected Sedona’s right-wing hippies to conservatives’ longtime interest in Indigeneity, from Barry Goldwater’s famous collection of hundreds of Hopi katsina carvings to “QAnon Shaman” Jake Angeli’s horned hat.
“That weird slippage between the Indian-identifying hippie and cowboy conservative is one that’s been with American culture a long time, and one that we’ve seen play out in Yavapai County a lot,” Young said.
From feminist to 'unschooling' advocate
Anam, the feminist-turned-vaccine skeptic, came to alternative wellness by way of poor health.
She studied biomedical research in college and, several years into her first job at a laboratory at UCLA, began feeling sick. She was accident-prone, losing her “cognitive abilities,” and spent a year or two in bed on disability.
It was in her 30s that she drifted away from politics, and swapped her thoroughly modern employment for the realm of “holistic” medicine. She began the travels that would one day deposit her in Arizona, and became involved in the Goddess movement of the 1970s and '80s, which venerated the feminine ideal.
She spent 11 years in a romantic relationship with a woman before drifting more toward the “New Age” scene, uncovering repressed sexual trauma from her youth and becoming romantically involved with a man. That’s when she moved to Sedona.
She gave birth to her daughter in 1999, and skipped most vaccines.
“It was not a political issue at all. It was more an intuitive level, and also an experiential level: Because when I was vaccinated, I went into a coma,” she said, referring to her health episode earlier in life.
Anam’s earliest political memory is around social justice. As a high schooler, she and her parents, both Democrats, protested the Nevada Test Site for nuclear weapons. She remembers doing a 200-mile walk to Mexico “for the orphanages.”
Now, at the age of 65, she's focused on “de-schooling.” The promotional materials for her professional services call for a shift away from "expert" knowledge, and a paradigm of "gaining intelligence in increments, going from novice to specialist," toward more intuitive learning and reasoning.
Like Dalton, the touchstone of her politics is “corruption.” She was put off by Sedona’s handling of a child care policy issue and believed their process for issuing contracts was rigged in favor of larger companies.
She briefly fell in with QAnon, the conspiracy movement that believed Trump was working to expose a cabal of child sex traffickers. But she became disillusioned with the movement, saying in that community, too, were corruption and deceit.
So instead she is working with Evans to build community at the Ultimate Light Mission.
They are two very different people. Anam has chosen not to participate in the political "sovereignty" movement that Evans has embraced. Anam is open and chatty, where Evans, navigating bankruptcy and previously the subject of antagonistic media coverage, refused an in-depth interview, citing "legal advice."
In their group conversation, Anam was fearful of artificial intelligence, where Evans saw it as a powerful tool.
Yet, staring down what they consider dark and deeply rooted political forces, they feel united by an ineffable bond. It spurs them to action.
“Shelley and I, we are like yin and yang,” Anam said.
“We’re blowing the lid off this, not in a political way,” she said. “We are supporting what really matters: Community, seniors, youth, the environment.”

Arizona doesn't do nearly enough to prevent child abuse | Letters
Arizona needs a better system of support for dysfunctional families that abuse or neglect children. Luckily, we already know what works.
The deaths of Arizona children Rebekah Baptiste, Emily Pike and Zariah Dodd are unacceptable tragedies. No child should experience abuse, and no family should suffer such loss.
When abuse is suspected, it must be reported.
But focusing only on reporting and investigation does not keep children safe. Nor does over-reporting prevent harm to children. It overwhelms the system, drives unnecessary investigations and erodes trust, making families less likely to seek the help that could prevent crises.
Real prevention happens earlier.
Arizona needs a stronger, better-connected system that links families to support before crisis occurs. We know what works: strategies like affordable childcare, accessible health care and Family Resource Centers, which are hubs of support for people raising children.
These proven solutions not only protect kids, they yield massive economic and social returns.
Our attention shouldn’t all be on improving DCS. Policymakers — and all of us — share the responsibility to create conditions that allow families to thrive.
Prevention is possible, and it’s the best way to keep children safe. It not only avoids unimaginable tragedy, but also creates an Arizona that is a great place to be child.
Claire Louge, Phoenix
Are the DBacks even a Major League team?
The Arizona Diamondbacks, as they have become prone to do, blew another lead to the last-place Colorado Rockies. Without relief pitching, it is a stretch to call them a Major League team.
Donald Wechsler, Peoria
No wonder Sedona hippies love MAGA red
Regarding The Arizona Republic story, “In Arizona's 'New Age Capital,' Sedona spiritualists are turning to Trump and the right:”
Is it that difficult to believe?
The MAGA movement wants smaller government and less interference. It wants to talk with our adversaries and avoid war. It sees big-government establishment people as profiteers making money off “public service.”
When MAGA took over the House, Senate and White House, today’s rebels were replacing the establishment. Party affiliation is not all that relevant.
So, the “Golden Age” is not too far removed from the “New Age.”
Charles Lopresto, Phoenix
Bark beetles are kind of like Trump
In 1998, our family owned a cabin northwest of Payson. One afternoon as we pulled into the driveway, my wife pointed out that the needles at the top of a 60-foot ponderosa pine had turned brown. Three smaller trees were in the same condition.
I called a tree specialist. Bark beetle, he said.
What, I asked, is a bark beetle?
In 2016, during his first campaign for president, Donald Trump said that news stories that cast him in a bad light were just fake news. We should only believe what he tells us to believe, he said.
I thought, this guy doesn’t have a chance. The second time around, Mr. Trump said we wouldn’t need to worry about the next election if he won this one. What did that mean?
MAGA gobbled up the U.S. Senate and House. The U.S. Supreme Court issued a get out of jail free card. And, on the president’s orders, masked men started dragging people off city streets.
What would be next, I wondered, troops?
Back in 1998, when the tree specialist schooled me on the bark beetle, I asked, what can I do to save the other trees?
He looked at me sideways and shook his head.
You don’t know it yet, but those trees are already dead.
R. C. Nelson, Tempe
Nasty WNBA game stunt is all about attitude
This was unusual for me, but E.J. Montini's column “You can bet how many sex toys will land on WNBA courts. That’s the problem” brought me over to his side with his insights about the young man who made a stunt out of throwing a sex toy on the court.
His motive? He thought “he would give it a try.”
Fortunately, he was arrested, even though his aim was terrible and he didn’t hit the court. Rather, he missed and hit a fan in the head. Talk about missing the broadside of a barn. Apparently, he has some manhood issues.
But Mr. Montini, I think, missed some points.
This man, whose name is hidden for some reason, will say or perhaps has said he is sorry. He will look contrite, his eyes looking down. “I’m sorry, your honor. I didn’t think this through, and I didn’t mean to hurt anyone ... blah, blah, blah.”
I’m guessing he won’t mean it. And were you to follow him around since his incident and watch him look at his friends, there would be hidden smiles.
That is the issue. His attitude is probably ingrained, and he won’t change.
Mark Williams, Phoenix
The costs of foolish immigration policy
The story of Peoria restaurant owner Kelly Yu (“Kelly Yu, Peoria restaurant owner, facing deportation under Trump administration”) says a lot about what is wrong with the Trump administration’s immigration policies. It also says a lot about what is wrong with us.
Kelly Yu did come to this country illegally. But since, she has given birth to a U.S. citizen daughter, got married, started a successful business that employs many people, followed all the rules towards achieving citizenship and gave back to her community.
And her reward for all that effort?
Sitting in a detention center in Eloy awaiting deportation. That makes no sense.
I don’t think people who have U.S. citizen children should be eligible for deportation unless they commit a serious crime. I also don’t think we should deport people whose contributions to our country outweigh any illegal entry decades ago.
There needs to be some calculation of the cost of removal. In other words, what are we losing by removing someone from our country and their community?
With Kelly Yu, it seems like we are losing a lot. A mother, a wife, a taxpayer who employs dozens of other taxpayers, a popular restaurant owner, a community participant.
She seems like someone we should recruit to be here.
Dan Peel, Scottsdale
